items.text: I feel free to make my own choices about how I spend my time each day.
items.rationale: Directly reflects the experience of volitional choice and self-governance, core to autonomy.

items.text: The things I do in my life are genuinely my own decisions, not obligations imposed by others.
items.rationale: Captures the sense of internal locus of causality and freedom from external pressure.

items.text: I pursue my goals because they truly matter to me, not because someone else expects me to.
items.rationale: Reflects intrinsic motivation and self-endorsed values, hallmarks of autonomy satisfaction.

items.text: When I look at my daily activities, they feel like expressions of who I really am.
items.rationale: Taps into authentic self-expression and congruence between actions and identity.

items.text: I often feel pressured to do things I wouldn't choose on my own.
items.rationale: Reverse-scored item capturing autonomy frustration through perceived external control.

items.text: People who know me would say I live life on my own terms.
items.rationale: Third-person observation format capturing self-determination and personal agency.

items.text: I have a strong sense of ownership over the direction my life is taking.
items.rationale: Reflects perceived authorship of one's life trajectory, central to autonomy need satisfaction.

items.text: Most of my actions feel forced rather than freely chosen.
items.rationale: Reverse-scored item directly assessing lack of volition and autonomy frustration.

items.text: I can openly express my opinions and preferences in most situations without fear of consequences.
items.rationale: Captures freedom of self-expression, a behavioral manifestation of autonomy satisfaction.

items.text: Even when I follow rules or guidelines, I understand and agree with the reasons behind them.
items.rationale: Reflects integrated regulation—compliance that feels autonomous because the rationale is internalized.

items.text: I rarely get to decide how I approach my work or responsibilities.
items.rationale: Reverse-scored item assessing lack of choice and self-direction in daily functioning.

items.text: My interests and values are the primary drivers of what I choose to do.
items.rationale: Directly taps intrinsic and identified motivation stemming from autonomy satisfaction.

items.text: I feel like I can be my authentic self in most areas of my life.
items.rationale: Authenticity is closely tied to autonomy but could also reflect social acceptance (relatedness).

items.text: I have the freedom to try new approaches when something isn't working for me.
items.rationale: Captures volitional flexibility, but trying new approaches also implies competence-seeking behavior.

items.text: I feel comfortable being myself around the people in my life because no one tries to control me.
items.rationale: Blends autonomy (freedom from control) with relatedness (comfort in social relationships).

items.text: I am effective at handling the challenges that come my way.
items.rationale: Directly assesses perceived effectiveness and mastery, the core of competence need satisfaction.

items.text: When I take on a difficult task, I generally feel confident I can succeed.
items.rationale: Captures self-efficacy and mastery expectation, central facets of competence.

items.text: I often feel like I'm not good enough at the things I need to do.
items.rationale: Reverse-scored item reflecting competence frustration and perceived inadequacy.

items.text: People tend to come to me for help because they see me as capable and knowledgeable.
items.rationale: Third-person behavioral indicator of perceived competence and expertise recognition.

items.text: I regularly experience a sense of accomplishment from the things I do.
items.rationale: Accomplishment and mastery experiences are direct indicators of competence satisfaction.

items.text: I feel well-equipped with the skills I need to achieve my goals.
items.rationale: Assesses perceived skill adequacy relative to personal goals, a core competence appraisal.

items.text: I struggle to keep up with the demands placed on me.
items.rationale: Reverse-scored item capturing competence frustration through perceived inability to meet demands.

items.text: When I learn something new, I pick it up relatively quickly.
items.rationale: Reflects perceived learning efficacy and intellectual mastery, key to competence.

items.text: I can point to clear evidence of growth and improvement in areas that matter to me.
items.rationale: Perceived progress and skill development directly satisfy the need for competence.

items.text: Most days, I feel like I'm just going through the motions without really mastering anything.
items.rationale: Reverse-scored item reflecting stagnation and lack of mastery experience.

items.text: I handle unexpected problems with resourcefulness and creativity.
items.rationale: Behavioral description of adaptive coping that reflects perceived competence in novel situations.

items.text: I receive positive feedback about the quality of my work on a regular basis.
items.rationale: External validation of performance is a key environmental support for competence satisfaction.

items.text: I feel a deep sense of satisfaction when I overcome an obstacle through my own effort.
items.rationale: Primarily competence (mastery), but 'through my own effort' also touches on autonomy and self-initiation.

items.text: I enjoy taking on challenges because I know I have what it takes to figure things out.
items.rationale: Captures competence confidence but the enjoyment and approach motivation could also reflect autonomy.

items.text: I feel most capable when I'm working alongside others who bring out the best in me.
items.rationale: Competence is the primary focus (feeling capable), but the social facilitation element overlaps with relatedness.

items.text: I have close, warm relationships with people who genuinely care about me.
items.rationale: Directly assesses the experience of meaningful interpersonal bonds, the essence of relatedness.

items.text: I feel deeply connected to the people who are most important in my life.
items.rationale: Captures emotional closeness and attachment, core components of relatedness satisfaction.

items.text: There are people in my life who truly understand who I am.
items.rationale: Feeling known and understood by others is a fundamental aspect of relatedness need satisfaction.

items.text: I often feel lonely, even when I'm surrounded by other people.
items.rationale: Reverse-scored item capturing relatedness frustration through subjective isolation despite social contact.

items.text: The people around me make me feel valued and appreciated.
items.rationale: Feeling valued by others directly reflects interpersonal warmth and relatedness satisfaction.

items.text: I belong to a community or group where I feel like I truly fit in.
items.rationale: Sense of belonging and social integration are central to the relatedness construct.

items.text: I find it difficult to open up to others or let people get close to me.
items.rationale: Reverse-scored item reflecting barriers to intimacy and relatedness frustration.

items.text: My friends and family would describe our relationships as mutually supportive and caring.
items.rationale: Third-person perspective capturing reciprocal warmth, a hallmark of relatedness satisfaction.

items.text: I regularly share meaningful conversations with people I trust.
items.rationale: Behavioral indicator of deep social connection and interpersonal intimacy.

items.text: I feel excluded or on the outside looking in when it comes to social groups.
items.rationale: Reverse-scored item assessing social exclusion and unmet belonging needs.

items.text: When something good or bad happens to me, I have someone I can share it with right away.
items.rationale: Availability of responsive social partners reflects strong relatedness need satisfaction.

items.text: I genuinely enjoy spending time with the people in my daily life.
items.rationale: Positive affect in social interactions is a direct marker of relatedness satisfaction.

items.text: I feel most like myself when I'm with people who accept me without judgment.
items.rationale: Primarily relatedness (acceptance), but 'feeling like myself' also touches on autonomy and authenticity.

items.text: Having people who believe in me gives me the confidence to take on new challenges.
items.rationale: Social support is relatedness, but the confidence and challenge-seeking elements overlap with competence.

items.text: I feel empowered to make my own decisions because the people around me support and encourage me.
items.rationale: Social support satisfies relatedness, but the empowerment and decision-making language maps onto autonomy.
